questions.text: Ebola virus comes under which Biosafety level category as given by WHO? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 4.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Ebola virus is classified under Biosafety Level 4 (BSL-4) by WHO, indicating it is one of the most dangerous pathogens requiring the highest level of containment.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with eclampsia is on a maintenance dose of MgSO₄. When will you stop MgSO₄? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Urine output 60ml in 4hr

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MgSO₄ should be stopped if the patient’s urine output is less than 30 ml per hour (or 60 ml in 4 hours), as this indicates poor excretion and risk of magnesium toxicity.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic alcohol use has developed confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible for this presentation? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin B1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with chronic alcohol use presenting with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, a Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency leading to Wernicke's Encephalopathy should be considered.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding a confounding factor? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: It can be reduced by matching

options.label: B
options.text: It is associated individually with both cause and effect

options.label: C
options.text: It is distributed equally in both study and control groups

options.label: D
options.text: It is associated with the exposure of the study

questions.correct_answer: C. It is distributed equally in both study and control groups
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is distributed equally in both study and control groups

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Confounding can be removed by
  • ➤ Confounding can be removed by
  • ➤ 1. Matching → MC used /simplest method
  • ➤ 2. Randomization → 2nd Best Method
  • ➤ 3. Restriction
  • ➤ 4. Stratification
  • ➤ 5. Statistical Modelling / Multivariate analysis (MVA)
  • ➤ 6. Stratified Randomization → Overall Best Method

questions.text: A lady with history of smoking presents with nipple discharge. She is diagnosed with duct ectasia. What is the procedure to be done? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hadfield procedure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Hadfield procedure is used to excise multiple affected ducts in patients with duct ectasia.

questions.text: The Thymus gland is specialized in identifying the molecules of the Major Histocompatibility Complex that are presented to it. It discerns whether these cells belong to the body's own or are of foreign origin. Which specific gene is accountable for this function? ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) AIRE

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The AIRE gene is crucial for promoting self-tolerance by ensuring that developing T cells in the thymus are exposed to self-antigens, thus preventing autoimmune diseases.

questions.text: Identify the sign and the tendon ruptured in the image given below: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Proximal biceps tendon rupture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The deformity shown in the given image in the question is seen in proximal biceps tendon rupture and is called Popeye deformity.
  • ➤ The deformity shown in the given image in the question is seen in proximal biceps tendon rupture and is called Popeye deformity.

questions.text: Choose the egg belonging to the following parasite from the column B? ( INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome presents with symptoms suggestive of a gastrinoma. Which of the following is the most common site of occurrence in MEN 1 syndrome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Duodenum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In patients with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. Gastrinomas are the most common functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with MEN 1 and are often found in the first and second parts of the duodenum.
  • • Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) Overview :
  • • Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) Overview
  • • MEN 1 is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the endocrine glands, leading to the development of multiple endocrine tumors. The main features of MEN 1 include: Parathyroid tumors : These cause hyperparathyroidism, the most common feature of MEN 1. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) : These tumors can be functional (producing hormones) or non-functional. Functional NETs include gastrinomas, insulinomas (causing hypoglycemia), glucagonomas, and VIPomas. Pituitary tumors : These are usually benign but can secrete various hormones, leading to different clinical manifestations such as prolactinomas, growth hormone-secreting tumors (acromegaly), and ACTH-secreting tumors (Cushing's disease).
  • • MEN 1 is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the endocrine glands, leading to the development of multiple endocrine tumors.
  • • The main features of MEN 1 include: Parathyroid tumors : These cause hyperparathyroidism, the most common feature of MEN 1. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) : These tumors can be functional (producing hormones) or non-functional. Functional NETs include gastrinomas, insulinomas (causing hypoglycemia), glucagonomas, and VIPomas. Pituitary tumors : These are usually benign but can secrete various hormones, leading to different clinical manifestations such as prolactinomas, growth hormone-secreting tumors (acromegaly), and ACTH-secreting tumors (Cushing's disease).
  • • Parathyroid tumors : These cause hyperparathyroidism, the most common feature of MEN 1. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) : These tumors can be functional (producing hormones) or non-functional. Functional NETs include gastrinomas, insulinomas (causing hypoglycemia), glucagonomas, and VIPomas. Pituitary tumors : These are usually benign but can secrete various hormones, leading to different clinical manifestations such as prolactinomas, growth hormone-secreting tumors (acromegaly), and ACTH-secreting tumors (Cushing's disease).
  • • Parathyroid tumors : These cause hyperparathyroidism, the most common feature of MEN 1.
  • • Parathyroid tumors
  • • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) : These tumors can be functional (producing hormones) or non-functional. Functional NETs include gastrinomas, insulinomas (causing hypoglycemia), glucagonomas, and VIPomas.
  • • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs)
  • • Pituitary tumors : These are usually benign but can secrete various hormones, leading to different clinical manifestations such as prolactinomas, growth hormone-secreting tumors (acromegaly), and ACTH-secreting tumors (Cushing's disease).
  • • Pituitary tumors
  • • Gastrinoma and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome :
  • • Gastrinoma and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome
  • • Gastrinomas are associated with increased gastric acid production and can lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by severe peptic ulcers and gastrin overproduction.
  • • Gastrinomas are associated with increased gastric acid production and can lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by severe peptic ulcers and gastrin overproduction.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Jejunum: Gastrinomas are less commonly found in the jejunum compared to the duodenum in MEN 1 syndrome.
  • • Option A. Jejunum:
  • • Option B. Ileum: The ileum is not a common site for gastrinomas in MEN 1 syndrome. The duodenum is the primary site.
  • • Option B. Ileum:
  • • Option D. Stomach: While gastrinomas can theoretically occur in the stomach, they are most commonly found in the duodenum in patients with MEN 1 syndrome.
  • • Option D. Stomach:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In MEN 1 syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. They are the most frequent functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with this genetic disorder.

questions.text: A patient recovered from Covid-19, treated with steroids, now presents with nasal discharge for 3 weeks. What does the histopathological image indicate? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mucor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The histopathological image shows broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, typical of Mucor species, suggesting a diagnosis of mucormycosis.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Aspergillus : Typically shows septate hyphae with acute angle branching.
  • • Option B. Aspergillus
  • • Option C. Candida : Forms yeast cells and pseudohyphae, not hyphae.
  • • Option C. Candida
  • • Option D. Trichosporon : Forms hyaline hyphae and arthroconidia, different from what is seen in the image.
  • • Option D. Trichosporon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Mucor is the cause of fungal infections characterized by broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those recently treated with steroids post-Covid-19 infection.

questions.text: A 6-months-old child presented with cyanosis and fatigue. His chest X ray is shown below. What is the most likely sign and diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Snowman sign, Supracardiac TAPVC

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given X-ray shows a case of total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation (TAPVC) with figure of 8 or snowman or cottage-loaf appearance .
  • • figure of 8 or snowman or cottage-loaf appearance
  • • TAPVC:
  • • TAPVC:
  • • TAPVC is a condition in which pulmonary veins drain directly or indirectly into the right atrium rather than the left atrium. As a result, pulmonary venous blood flow drains abnormally into the systemic venous circulation. It is a cyanotic heart disease with congestive heart failure symptoms. The patients are irritable and failure to thrive.
  • • TAPVC is a condition in which pulmonary veins drain directly or indirectly into the right atrium rather than the left atrium. As a result, pulmonary venous blood flow drains abnormally into the systemic venous circulation.
  • • pulmonary veins drain directly or indirectly into the right atrium rather than the left atrium.
  • • It is a cyanotic heart disease with congestive heart failure symptoms. The patients are irritable and failure to thrive.
  • • The patients are irritable and failure to thrive.
  • • The following types are seen:
  • • The following types are seen:
  • • I. Supra cardiac – Most common type
  • • I. Supra cardiac –
  • • II. Cardiac
  • • II. Cardiac
  • • III. Infra cardiac – Most common type for obstruction (worst prognosis)
  • • III. Infra cardiac –
  • • (worst prognosis)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cottage loaf, truncus arteriosus: Truncus arteriosus involves a single arterial trunk coming from the heart, not typically showing a snowman sign.
  • • Option A. Cottage loaf, truncus arteriosus:
  • • Option C. Egg on side, TGA (Transposition of the Great Arteries): This condition typically shows an "egg on a string" appearance due to the abnormal positioning of the great arteries.
  • • Option C. Egg on side, TGA (Transposition of the Great Arteries):
  • • Option D. Boot shaped heart, TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot): Characterized by a boot-shaped heart on X-ray due to right ventricular hypertrophy; not the pattern observed in this image.'
  • • Option D. Boot shaped heart, TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "snowman sign" on a chest X-ray in a child presenting with cyanosis and fatigue is highly suggestive of Supracardiac TAPVC.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient comes to the clinic with a history of rapidly enlarging swelling in her right breast for the last 15 days. During the physical examination, there was a local rise in temperature, and the lump was partially mobile over the chest wall. What could be the probable diagnosis for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inflammatory carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In the given scenario, the patient's rapid onset of disease and examination findings suggest inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, which is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. Inflammatory breast cancer typically presents with brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (Peau d'orange appearance), along with a breast lump. Skin biopsy is used to diagnose inflammatory breast cancer. The treatment for inflammatory breast cancer includes combined-modality treatment, such as neoadjuvant chemotherapy, mastectomy, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy for ER-positive tumors, and Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors.
  • ➤ In the given scenario, the patient's rapid onset of disease and examination findings suggest inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, which is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer.
  • ➤ Inflammatory breast cancer typically presents with brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (Peau d'orange appearance), along with a breast lump.
  • ➤ Skin biopsy is used to diagnose inflammatory breast cancer.
  • ➤ The treatment for inflammatory breast cancer includes combined-modality treatment, such as neoadjuvant chemotherapy, mastectomy, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy for ER-positive tumors, and Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaint of abdominal pain. Routine investigations were unremarkable. On observation, the urine turned black on standing. Which of the following enzymes is likely to be defective in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Homogentisate oxidase

questions.text: All-trans retinoic acid is used in the treatment of tumor that is associated with which of the following genetic aberrations? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) PML-RARA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which is characterized by the PML-RARA fusion gene resulting from the t(15;17) translocation. This treatment promotes the differentiation of leukemic promyelocytes, improving clinical outcomes in APL patients.

questions.text: A patient complains of decreased sensation in the lateral 3 ½ fingers of the palmar side of the right hand along with difficulty moving the upper phalanx of the thumb. Associated thenar atrophy is also present. What is the associated nerve injury in this case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The high median nerve injury is characterized by sensory loss in the lateral 3 ½ fingers on the palmar side, difficulty moving the thumb, and associated thenar atrophy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding neutrophil extracellular trapping (NET)? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: It is detected in blood during sepsis

options.label: B
options.text: It is produced in response to bacterial infection.

options.label: D
options.text: It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes.

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mitochondrial DNA is seen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are networks of nuclear DNA from neutrophils combined with antimicrobial enzymes and peptides, produced in response to bacterial and fungal infections. They play a crucial role in trapping and neutralizing pathogens. The presence of mitochondrial DNA in NETs is incorrect, as NETs are composed of nuclear chromatin.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the area marked green in the image below? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Opponens pollicis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The palmar aspect of the first metacarpal is the area marked in the image. At this location, the opponens pollicis muscle inserts.
  • • Opponens pollicis: Origin: Tubercle of the trapezium and flexor retinaculum Insertion: Whole length of the lateral border and adjoining lateral half of the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal. Action: Flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.
  • • Opponens pollicis:
  • • Opponens pollicis:
  • • Origin: Tubercle of the trapezium and flexor retinaculum
  • • Origin:
  • • Insertion: Whole length of the lateral border and adjoining lateral half of the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal.
  • • Insertion:
  • • Action: Flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.
  • • Action:
  • • The image below shows various intrinsic muscles of the hand.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A . Abductor Pollicis Longus: Abductor pollicis longus is not directly attached to the first metacarpal. It originates from the posterior surface of the ulna and radius and inserts into the base of the first metacarpal bone. Its primary action is to abduct the thumb away from the palm.
  • • Option A
  • • Abductor Pollicis Longus:
  • • Option B. Palmar Interossei: The palmar interossei muscles are located between the metacarpal bones in the palm of the hand. They are responsible for adducting the fingers toward the midline of the hand. They are not directly attached to the first metacarpal.
  • • Option B.
  • • Palmar Interossei:
  • • Option D . Flexor Pollicis Brevis: The flexor pollicis brevis muscle has two heads: the superficial head and the deep head. The superficial head originates from the flexor retinaculum, while the deep head originates from the trapezoid and capitate bones.
  • • Option D
  • • Flexor Pollicis Brevis:
  • • Both heads of the flexor pollicis brevis insert into the base of the first metacarpal bone. The main action of the flexor pollicis brevis is to flex the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint.
  • • Both heads of the flexor pollicis brevis insert into the base of the first metacarpal bone.
  • • The main action of the flexor pollicis brevis is to flex the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The opponens pollicis muscle originates from the flexor retinaculum and the tubercles of the trapezium bone. It inserts into the first metacarpal bone. The primary action of the opponens pollicis is to oppose the thumb, allowing for the grasping and pinching movements of the thumb.
  • ➤ The opponens pollicis muscle originates from the flexor retinaculum and the tubercles of the trapezium bone. It inserts into the first metacarpal bone.
  • ➤ The primary action of the opponens pollicis is to oppose the thumb, allowing for the grasping and pinching movements of the thumb.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with a history of low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain and amenorrhea for six months. On examination, a pelvic mass is felt on the left side and signs of ascites are positive. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tuberculosis with tubo-ovarian mass

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is the most likely diagnosis in view of the following points Age Symptoms: low grade fever, weight loss, pain and amenorrhoea Adnexal mass with ascites
  • • This is the most likely diagnosis in view of the following points Age Symptoms: low grade fever, weight loss, pain and amenorrhoea Adnexal mass with ascites
  • • Age Symptoms: low grade fever, weight loss, pain and amenorrhoea Adnexal mass with ascites
  • • Age
  • • Symptoms: low grade fever, weight loss, pain and amenorrhoea
  • • Adnexal mass with ascites
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Ovarian malignancy : Ovarian malignancy may present with weight loss, ascites and a pelvic mass. But a young age and amenorrhea do not go in favor of ovarian malignancy
  • • Option B. Ovarian malignancy
  • • Option C. Ectopic pregnancy : Ectopic pregnancy will be an acute presentation and will not present with fever/ weight loss
  • • Option C. Ectopic pregnancy
  • • Option D. Submucous fibroid : Submucous fibroid presents with menorrhagia/ inter-menstrual bleeding and the uterus will be uniformly enlarged. There will not be any pelvic mass.
  • • Option D. Submucous fibroid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tuberculosis with a tubo-ovarian mass is suspected in young patients presenting with low-grade fever, weight loss, amenorrhea, and a pelvic mass with signs of ascites.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 141, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 141, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: What is the most common complication of the central line insertion below the marked bone? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Arterial puncture

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The bone indicated in the image above is the left clavicle. An arterial puncture is the most common complication of a central line insertion below this bone.
  • • Complications of central vein catheterization are - Arterial puncture- this is the most common complication. Cardiac tamponade is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle. Pneumothorax- injury to the underlying pleura may lead to pneumothorax. This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization. Chylothorax can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common. Injury to the associated nerves like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords. Thromboembolism leading to venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism is more common with femoral veins. Infections
  • • Complications of central vein catheterization are - Arterial puncture- this is the most common complication. Cardiac tamponade is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle. Pneumothorax- injury to the underlying pleura may lead to pneumothorax. This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization. Chylothorax can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common. Injury to the associated nerves like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords. Thromboembolism leading to venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism is more common with femoral veins. Infections
  • • Complications of central vein catheterization are -
  • • Arterial puncture- this is the most common complication. Cardiac tamponade is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle. Pneumothorax- injury to the underlying pleura may lead to pneumothorax. This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization. Chylothorax can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common. Injury to the associated nerves like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords. Thromboembolism leading to venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism is more common with femoral veins. Infections
  • • Arterial puncture- this is the most common complication.
  • • Cardiac tamponade is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle.
  • • Pneumothorax- injury to the underlying pleura may lead to pneumothorax. This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization.
  • • Chylothorax can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common.
  • • Injury to the associated nerves like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords.
  • • Thromboembolism leading to venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism is more common with femoral veins.
  • • Infections
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B . Thrombophlebitis : Thrombophlebitis refers to inflammation of a vein associated with clot formation. While thrombophlebitis can occur following any central line placement, it's more commonly associated with peripheral IV lines. However, central venous catheters are more commonly associated with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is the formation of a blood clot inside the larger, deeper veins.
  • • Option B
  • • Thrombophlebitis
  • • Option C. Empyema : Empyema refers to the accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity. While empyema itself is not a direct complication of central line placement, pneumothorax or hemothorax (air or blood in the pleural space, respectively) caused by central line placement can lead to infection and subsequently empyema if not recognized and treated.
  • • Option C.
  • • Empyema
  • • Option D . Chylothorax : Chylothorax is the accumulation of lymphatic fluid in the pleural space. This can happen if the thoracic duct is damaged. The thoracic duct is a major lymphatic vessel that runs in the thorax but is not typically at risk with subclavian line placement. Chylothorax would be more of a concern with procedures that are done in close proximity to the thoracic duct, like surgeries or interventions in the mediastinum or around the esophagus.
  • • Option D
  • • Chylothorax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Arterial puncture is one of the most common complications associated with the subclavian approach for central venous catheter placement. The subclavian artery lies directly beneath the vein, so inadvertent puncture of the artery can occur if the needle is advanced too deeply or at an incorrect angle. Accidental puncture of the subclavian artery can lead to complications such as hematoma, hemothorax, and can also be problematic if not recognized because threading a catheter into the arterial system can have catastrophic consequences.
  • ➤ Arterial puncture

questions.text: A young girl presented with a history of multiple episodes of loss of consciousness that lasted for 5-10 minutes. These episodes occur only in front of family members and only in the daytime. The patient can recall the conversation that happened around her during these episodes; there is no history of tongue bite and no incontinence. What is the preferred treatment? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Treat with behavioral therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The preferred treatment for conversion disorder, which manifests with pseudoseizures, is behavioral therapy, not antiepileptic drugs or other seizure management strategies.

questions.text: In a given population, total births were 4050 including 50 stillbirths in a given year. 50 neonates die within the first 7 days of life, and an additional 150 die within 8-28 days of life. What is the Neonatal mortality rate in the population? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 50

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) is calculated as the number of neonatal deaths per 1000 live births.

questions.text: Match the following molecules with their carriers in plasma: ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct pairs are as follows:
  • ➤ The correct pairs are as follows:
  • ➤ 1. Thyroxine - b. Pre-albumin
  • ➤ 2. Vitamin B12 - c. Transcobalamin
  • ➤ 3. Hemoglobin - d. Haptoglobin
  • ➤ 4. Heme - a. Hemopexin

questions.text: Identify the cause(s) that result in non-scarring alopecia from the following options: ( INICET May 2023) Alopecia areata Telogen effluvium Androgenic alopecia Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Additional Information

questions.text: Not included in STEPS approach for Non-communicable diseases is (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Blood grouping

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The WHO STEPS approach for non-communicable disease (NCD) risk factor & STROKE surveillance involves three steps: behavioral measurements, physical measurements, and biochemical measurements. These steps focus on key indicators related to NCDs and stroke surveillance.
  • • non-communicable disease (NCD) risk factor & STROKE surveillance
  • • The specific indicators include:
  • • The specific indicators include:
  • • Step 1: Behavioral measurements – (for both core & expanded indicators) Tobacco use, alcohol consumption, diet, exercise, history of raised blood pressure, and diabetes mellitus. Step 2: Physical measurements - Core indicators include height, weight, waist circumference, and blood pressure; expanded indicators include hip circumference and heart rate. Step 3: Biochemical measurements - Core indicators include blood glucose and blood lipids; expanded indicators include triglycerides and serum cholesterol levels.
  • • Step 1: Behavioral measurements – (for both core & expanded indicators) Tobacco use, alcohol consumption, diet, exercise, history of raised blood pressure, and diabetes mellitus.
  • • Step 1: Behavioral measurements
  • • Step 2: Physical measurements - Core indicators include height, weight, waist circumference, and blood pressure; expanded indicators include hip circumference and heart rate.
  • • Step 2: Physical measurements
  • • Step 3: Biochemical measurements - Core indicators include blood glucose and blood lipids; expanded indicators include triglycerides and serum cholesterol levels.
  • • Step 3: Biochemical measurements
  • • Blood grouping is not a part of the STEPS approach as it does not relate to the risk factors or measurements for NCDs.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Blood sugar: Included as a core biochemical measurement (blood glucose).
  • • Option A. Blood sugar:
  • • Option B. Blood pressure: Included as a core physical measurement.
  • • Option B. Blood pressure:
  • • Option D. Blood lipids: Included as a core biochemical measurement.
  • • Option D. Blood lipids:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The WHO STEPS approach for NCD risk factor surveillance includes behavioral, physical, and biochemical measurements, but blood grouping is not included in these indicators.

questions.text: What is the reason behind Senile Atrophy? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Reduced blood supply

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Senile atrophy is primarily due to reduced blood supply, leading to tissue shrinkage and loss of function with aging.

questions.text: Which of the following findings are seen in a high-resolution CT scan of fungal pneumonia?(INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: D
options.text: Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities

questions.correct_answer: D. Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Invasive aspergillosis
  • • HALO SIGN – Multiple nodules with central solid part and haziness around the lesion Seen in immunocompromised individuals with febrile neutropenia DOC – voriconazole
  • • HALO SIGN – Multiple nodules with central solid part and haziness around the lesion
  • • Seen in immunocompromised individuals with febrile neutropenia
  • • DOC – voriconazole
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Kerley lines: Commonly associated with interstitial edema and pulmonary congestion, not specifically fungal pneumonia.
  • • Option A. Kerley lines: Commonly
  • • Option B. Hilar lymph nodes: While enlargement can be seen in various conditions, it is not a specific finding for fungal pneumonia.
  • • Option B. Hilar lymph nodes:
  • • Option C. Pleural effusion: Although it may be present in various lung infections and conditions, it is not characteristic of fungal infections like invasive aspergillosis.
  • • Option C. Pleural effusion:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities on a high-resolution CT scan are indicative of fungal infections like invasive aspergillosis, especially in immunocompromised patients. Recognition of these signs is crucial for the timely initiation of appropriate antifungal therapy.

questions.text: A 30-year-man presents with swelling over knee joint. Biopsy reveals mononuclear and giant cells. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Osteoclastoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mononuclear giant cells in the histological findings is diagnostic for osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor.
  • ➤ Mononuclear giant cells in the histological findings is diagnostic for osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor.

questions.text: A 60-year-old farmer reports symptoms of fever, body pain, and a cough. A physical examination reveals a black lesion as depicted in the accompanying image. Laboratory tests confirm the presence of IgM antibodies indicative of Scrub Typhus infection. What treatment approach would be most advisable in this case? ( INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Doxycycline alone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This black lesion is Eschar and this is the acute case of Scrub Typhus.
  • • Causative organism - Rickettsia tsutsugamushi; Vector - Mite
  • • The preferred approach depends on the severity of the condition and individual patient considerations.
  • • Option A. Doxycycline Alone :
  • • Option A. Doxycycline Alone
  • • Use : This is the first-line treatment for Scrub Typhus. Mechanism : Doxycycline works by inhibiting protein synthesis in bacteria, effectively controlling the infection. Why Prefer : It's highly effective and typically well-tolerated, making it suitable for most cases unless contraindicated.
  • • Use : This is the first-line treatment for Scrub Typhus.
  • • Use
  • • Mechanism : Doxycycline works by inhibiting protein synthesis in bacteria, effectively controlling the infection.
  • • Mechanism
  • • Why Prefer : It's highly effective and typically well-tolerated, making it suitable for most cases unless contraindicated.
  • • Why Prefer
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Doxycycline + Azithromycin : Used when there is co-infection with other pathogens that azithromycin can cover or when doxycycline alone isn't adequately effective.
  • • Option B. Doxycycline + Azithromycin
  • • Option C. Ceftriaxone + Doxycycline : This combination might be used in more severe cases or when the patient has complications that might benefit from a broader antibiotic coverage.
  • • Option C. Ceftriaxone + Doxycycline
  • • Option D. Ceftriaxone Alone : While effective against many types of bacteria, it's not the targeted treatment for Scrub Typhus and generally not recommended unless other options are contraindicated.
  • • Option D. Ceftriaxone Alone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Doxycycline alone is usually sufficient and most advisable for uncomplicated Scrub Typhus. Combination therapies may be considered in specific clinical scenarios where co-infections or severe presentations are evident.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Brown-Séquard syndrome? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.correct_answer: A. Complete transection of spinal cord
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Complete transection of spinal cord

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brown-Séquard syndrome is characterized by hemisection of the spinal cord, leading to ipsilateral loss of vibration, touch, and proprioception, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature. Complete transection of the spinal cord is not a feature of this syndrome

questions.text: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of dark-colored stools to the OPD. After undergoing endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper GI bleed. Which of the following structures is used as a demarcation point to differentiate it from a lower GI bleed?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Ligament of Treitz

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ligament of Treitz is the anatomical demarcation point used to differentiate upper gastrointestinal bleeding (proximal to the ligament) from lower gastrointestinal bleeding (distal to the ligament).

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who is a known case of COPD presented with acute exacerbation and in type 2 respiratory failure was admitted to the ICU. Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the initial management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.correct_answer: A. Non-Invasive PPV should be given
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Non-Invasive PPV should be given

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a COPD patient presenting with acute exacerbation and respiratory failure, non-invasive ventilation is the preferred initial management strategy to stabilize the patient's respiratory status, reducing the need for intubation and potentially improving clinical outcomes.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/COPD/chapter 292

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with obstructive jaundice has a distended gall bladder and a dilated common bile duct and intrahepatic biliary radicles on ultrasound. Which of the following will be most useful to localize the cause? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obstructive jaundice is a condition in which there is a blockage of the flow of bile out of the liver. This results in redirection of excess bile and its by-products into the blood, and bile excretion from the body is incomplete
  • ➤ Symptoms of obstructive jaundice include yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes; paler stools and darker urine; and intense itching.
  • ➤ The most common cause of obstructive jaundice is the presence of CBD stones (choledocholithiasis). Other causes of obstructive jaundice are tumors, trauma, cysts, and inflammation in the bile ducts.

questions.text: Which ganglia is affected due to the involvement of the nerve located at the marked area? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pterygopalatine ganglion is located in the pterygopalatine fossa and is involved in the parasympathetic innervation of the lacrimal, nasal, and palatine glands. This ganglion is specifically affected by involvement in the region marked in the skull image.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of waxing and waning jaundice in an alcoholic patient with dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct on CT examination? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Periampullary carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Periampullary carcinoma (option B) is the most likely cause of waxing and waning jaundice in an alcoholic patient with dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct on CT examination due to its anatomical location and its potential to obstruct both ducts.

questions.text: A patient was in excruciating pain all over the body and went to hospital. This pain occurs after exercise. Patient has anemia with elongated RBCs. Sickle cell anemia diagnosis was made. Which of the following is true about this disease?(FMGE JAN 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Valine substituted by glutamate at 6 th position

options.label: B
options.text: Valine substituted by glutamate at 5 th position

options.label: C
options.text: Glutamate substituted by valine at 5 th position

options.label: D
options.text: Glutamate substituted by valine at 6 th position

questions.correct_answer: D. Glutamate substituted by valine at 6 th position
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glutamate substituted by valine at 6thposition

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • SCA is due to point mutation in the 6 th codon of beta globin that leads to the replacement of a Glutamate (Polar) residue with a Valine (Nonpolar) residue This substitution significantly alters the hemoglobin's physical properties, leading to the polymerization of hemoglobin under low oxygen conditions and causing the red blood cells to assume a sickle shape. These sickled cells lead to vascular occlusions and a range of complications including severe pain crises, often triggered by conditions such as strenuous exercise.
  • • SCA is due to point mutation in the 6 th codon of beta globin that leads to the replacement of a Glutamate (Polar) residue with a Valine (Nonpolar) residue
  • • This substitution significantly alters the hemoglobin's physical properties, leading to the polymerization of hemoglobin under low oxygen conditions and causing the red blood cells to assume a sickle shape. These sickled cells lead to vascular occlusions and a range of complications including severe pain crises, often triggered by conditions such as strenuous exercise.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diagnosis of SCA can be done by:
  • ➤ Diagnosis of SCA can be done by:
  • ➤ Hb electrophoresis—HbS migrate slower in an electric field because of less negative charge, because glutamate is replaced by valine Sickling Test HPLC to fractionate Hb Isoelectric Focusing Direct diagnosis by RFLP.
  • ➤ Hb electrophoresis—HbS migrate slower in an electric field because of less negative charge, because glutamate is replaced by valine
  • ➤ Sickling Test
  • ➤ HPLC to fractionate Hb
  • ➤ Isoelectric Focusing
  • ➤ Direct diagnosis by RFLP.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 657
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 657

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Cyclophosphamide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent used to treat various cancers and autoimmune diseases. One of its known side effects is the increased risk of developing bladder carcinoma. This is due to the metabolite acrolein, which can cause urothelial damage leading to malignancy. Long-term use or high doses of cyclophosphamide significantly elevate this risk.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Cisplatin: Cisplatin is a chemotherapy drug effective against various cancers, including testicular, ovarian, and bladder cancer. However, it is not specifically associated with the development of bladder carcinoma as a side effect.
  • • Option B. Cisplatin:
  • • Option C. Taxane (e.g., paclitaxel, docetaxel): Taxanes are chemotherapeutic agents used in treating breast, ovarian, and lung cancers. They are not linked to bladder carcinoma development.
  • • Option C. Taxane (e.g., paclitaxel, docetaxel):
  • • Option D. Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen is primarily used to treat breast cancer. While it can increase the risk of endometrial cancer due to its estrogen-like effects on uterine tissue, it is not associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer.
  • • Option D. Tamoxifen:
  • • Additional Information on Drugs Associated with Bladder Cancer: Several drugs have been associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer, including:
  • • Additional Information on Drugs Associated with Bladder Cancer:
  • • Pioglitazone : A drug used to treat type 2 diabetes. Aristolochic acid : Found in some herbal remedies. Phenacetin : An analgesic and antipyretic. Aminosalicylates : Used in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.
  • • Pioglitazone : A drug used to treat type 2 diabetes.
  • • Pioglitazone
  • • Aristolochic acid : Found in some herbal remedies.
  • • Aristolochic acid
  • • Phenacetin : An analgesic and antipyretic.
  • • Phenacetin
  • • Aminosalicylates : Used in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.
  • • Aminosalicylates

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma due to its metabolite acrolein, which can damage the bladder lining.

questions.text: Increased firing of which of the following is responsible for the occurrence of scissoring gait? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Obturator nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Scissoring gait is characterized by the crossing of the legs while walking, which resembles the closing of a pair of scissors. This gait abnormality is primarily due to increased tone and overactivity of the adductor muscles of the thighs, which are responsible for bringing the legs together.
  • • The adductor muscles are innervated by the obturator nerve . Increased firing or hyperactivity of the obturator nerve leads to excessive contraction of the adductor muscles, resulting in the scissoring motion seen in this gait disorder.
  • • adductor muscles
  • • obturator nerve
  • • Treatment options for scissoring gait may include interventions such as obturator nerve cryoneurolysis, where the obturator nerve is intentionally damaged to reduce muscle spasticity and improve gait.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Femoral nerve: This nerve innervates the anterior compartment of the thigh, including the quadriceps muscles, which are involved in knee extension, not adduction.
  • • Option A. Femoral nerve:
  • • Option B. Superior gluteal nerve: This nerve innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles, which are involved in hip abduction and stabilization, not adduction.
  • • Option B. Superior gluteal nerve:
  • • Option C. Inferior gluteal nerve: This nerve innervates the gluteus maximus muscle, which is primarily responsible for hip extension and lateral rotation, not adduction.
  • • Option C. Inferior gluteal nerve:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives
  • ➤ Scissoring gait is caused by increased firing of the obturator nerve, leading to overactivity of the adductor muscles of the thighs.
